user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of add_session_cookie:
```c
static void
add_session_cookie (struct Session *session,
                    struct MHD_Response *response)
{
  char cstr[256];
  snprintf (cstr,
            sizeof (cstr),
            "%s=%s",
            COOKIE_NAME,
            session->sid);
  if (MHD_NO ==
      MHD_add_response_header (response,
                               MHD_HTTP_HEADER_SET_COOKIE,
                               cstr))
  {
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to set session cookie header!\n");
  }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
static void
add_session_cookie (struct Session *session,
                    struct MHD_Response *response)
{
  char cstr[256];
  snprintf (cstr,
            sizeof (cstr),
            "%s=%s",
            COOKIE_NAME,
            session->sid);
  if (MHD_NO ==
      MHD_add_response_header (response,
                               MHD_HTTP_HEADER_SET_COOKIE,
                               cstr))
  {
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to set session cookie header!\n");
  }
}

```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the provided fragment: every statement (the snprintf call and the conditional call to MHD_add_response_header and its error-reporting branch) is reachable at run-time. A violation would occur only in a modified/hypothetical scenario — for example, if the conditional were a compile-time constant false (e.g. if (0) { ... }) or if an unconditional return or goto preceding the snprintf made the remainder of the function unreachable, or if MHD_add_response_header were a macro that always expands to a constant value causing the if-branch to be provably never taken.
